data.text: Cycle Touring the Lejog: Should I Pick 1x11 Gears or 2x11?
Hi thinking of doing the lejog will 1x11 gears be fine ?

I wouldn’t be choosing a 1x setup if I’m being honest. With a 1x setup you will find that you either don’t have a high enough gear on long flat/tailwind/slightly downhill days, and if you do, you might find some of the hills a slog with your kit. I’m quite a 1x fan but I can live without the high gear for a casual day ride, but over distance - I’d get very fed up with it very quickly!
data.author: Phil Tomlinson

data.text: ^^ this
data.author: Ben Bethell

data.text: what would you recommend then pal ive also got a ridgeback hybrid 3x9 and a planet x 2x11
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: It’s all a little bit - how long is a piece of string. You need a good spread of gear inches. I have a 31/48 x 34/11
data.author: Ben Bethell

data.text: Nice one mate
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: Why not? I regularly tour on a carbon fibre On One Space Chicken with a 42 chain ring and an 11-42 cassette. Sure, shifting is a tad agricultural but it's fine by me. (My other bike is a Enigma Etape 3x10, but I enjoy them both)
data.author: Richard Barrett

data.text: on one free ranger me mate
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: Just noticed that some of Planet Xs carbon gravel forks even have mounting lugs now.
data.author: Richard Barrett

data.text: what set up do you run on your space chicken bags or panniers ?
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text:
As we stick to roads and wide tracks, we use racks and small Ortlieb panniers, which we find more than adequate for a week of credit card touring staying in hotels and B&Bs. We're very near being 70 so bugger camping. You'll find us here. https://www.cicerone.co.uk/gravel-biking-the-heads-of-the-valleys-route
Gravel biking the Heads of the Valleys route
cicerone.co.uk
data.author: Richard Barrett

data.text: cheer buddy
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: I’d be less worried about the high end and more worried about the big jumps between gears. I have both 1x and 2x and frequently find myself at the “wrong” cadence when. Riding on the road on my 1x. Having big jumps between gears means I can’t fix it like I can with my 2x.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: good point on cadence. With a loaded bike when you have to maintain cadence for a long period, being in between gears is minging.
data.author: Phil Tomlinson

data.text: adapt, improvise, overcome fellas. I’m running 1x10 on my new build road bike. Happy with it, regardless of jumps in hearing ratios.
data.author: Andy Clayton

data.text: and that’s great. It works for some but not for all. Personally, I’d take 2x all day long and have never had an issue with a front mech in 30+ years of riding. Worst case scenario is I end up with a 1x anyway, so it’s not an issue.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: no benefit to 1x over 2x. It's just a mental decision
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: did I state or imply there was..? No
data.author: Andy Clayton

data.text: If you are happy with it just do it. I have 1×11 and I wouldn't change it.
data.author: Ken Clarkson

data.text: Sure. I do all my touring on a 1x11. I’d make sure you have a nice low bottom gear for sure, but that applies to any time you go to devon & Cornwall on any bike
data.author: Chris Pugh

data.text: Well people have been round the world on single speed so why not
data.author: David Kitson

data.text: Thanks all
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: You should be OK. The way the gear ratios work out, on 1x11 you're losing one or two gears either at the top, or at the bottom compared to 2x11. But when touring under load, the top is hardly ever needed, anyway, so as long as your cassette is on the larger side, you'll be fine. You'll definitely need the lower end for the southwestern part.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: nice one mate 11-42t
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: If that's what you're used to then go for it.
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: It’s more to do with the spread of ratios than the number of gears, but 1x are the way forward these days and create less failure points on the bike, which is a benefit.
data.author: Bikepacking & Cycle Touring UK

data.text: Bikepacking & Cycle Touring UK loads of people cite fewer failure points as a compelling reason for 1x. Yes. Technically correct. But so would riding a single speed and not many do that. I’d love to know how many people have had to abandon a ride due to a failed front mech. I bet it’s approaching zero. You start the ride with a 2x and if it fails you have a 1x, probably only losing the top gears. Or, you start with a 1x with larger jumps between gears. For road riding or long distances 2x just makes more sense to me.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: Yes you’ll be fine. I’ve done it on a loaded Surly. Good points raised but go with what you’re used to.
data.author: Graeme Dunbar

data.text: I've got both and 1x is just as good for the job, got me over the Pennines easy enough... Possibly if you are particularly unfit, maybe be slightly easier 2x?!
data.author: Eamon Kavanagh

data.text: how so? 2x doesn’t necessarily give you lower gears. Oh, and I like the phrase “particularly unfit”, I guess that’s why every pro team, semi pro team and elite amateurs all ride 2x. Because they’re “particularly unfit”….
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: Absolutely , however the incremental difference Inbetween gears is obviously smaller so making transition between gears possible slightly less/easier?! As I said 1x works just fine and dandy for me... 👍
data.author: Eamon Kavanagh

data.text: im quite fit just wasnt sure weather it be sound with 1x11 or ive got a road bike n hyrbid to just wasnt sure what would be best aiming for fast and lightweight
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: My road bike is 2x very fast but I wouldn't really use it for bikepacking... Both my MTB and gravel are 1x and I use both for my trips with all my camping kit... Just depends on the sort of terrain I'll be covering as to which bike I take...
data.author: Eamon Kavanagh

data.text: yeah that was i was thinking no to take the road bike what tyres do you run on your gravel for more road terrain im on 38c atm was thinking to come down to 30c
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: Currently on stock WTB Sendero 650x47C Road Plus.. Love the fact I can go pretty much anywhere on them, but like yourself may well opt for something bit more faster moving when on tarmac when I come to replace?!
data.author: Eamon Kavanagh

data.text: im running vittoria trail tech 700cx38c very good of road and very fast rolling on tarmac mate
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: Cool , I'll look into them , thanks for the info 👍
data.author: Eamon Kavanagh

data.text: Stock bottom gearing probably very similar. My Sonder - 40 chainring, 42 cassette. Trek Domane, 34 small chainring, 34 tooth at the back.
data.author: Simon Walford

data.text: Run what you have .. but it’s not something that I would choose
data.author: David Riley

data.text: S'pose my tuppence would be to ask how do you want to do your lejog? If you want to do it quickly, then probably a 1x wouldn't work. However, if you want to immerse yourself in the journey, then it would be fine. I use 1x for all my riding (11/44 X 42 I think) but I love to take my time and enjoy the view.
data.author: Patrick Civil

data.text: I think that's an impossible question to answer. I needed all my gears (50/34 - 11/32) to complete 215km Audax on Sunday. But another guy was faster than me on a fixie single speed. So it all depends on the rider.
data.author: Andrew Weaver

data.text: If that's what you've got then go for it 🙌
data.author: Ray 'Doozer' Cresswell

data.text: 1x11 does not mean anything. You want low enough gears to handle the hardest hills when you run out of energy. I had a 1x that I changed to 2x cause the lowest gear before the change had limits on steep stuff and I liked the existing 11 - 34 casette I had.
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: Prob b ok.. there’s nothing steep really but depending on ur route I suppose.
data.author: Mark Vance

data.text: The coastal route from LE to just beyond Moretonhampstead, the way it's laid out in Cicerone's guide, is full of short sharp climbs, easily in double digits. At least one I can remember about 20% - I was struggling to get purchase on the ground pushing the bike uphill. The rest, you're right, pretty much flat. Ish.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: sounds good! I think I chose quickest route… ur first day will b toughest, after that plain sailing 😎
data.author: Mark Vance

data.text: Yeah, the central part of Corwall is more or less flat, albeit still nice. The coast is full of ravines, for lack of a better word, where every stream carves out a wee dale, from 300ft or so down to the sea level. So it's literally all up and down, and steep at that. And you're right - the first two days were by far the hardest on the whole route. There were quite a few bigger climbs than that, but nothing anywhere near as steep. Mind you, I departed from the 'classic' from Preston to stay in Lancaster where I live, and later on adlibbed around the Scottish west coast... But I cycled all other 'classic' sections on other occasions, and no, nowt compares to Cornwall.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: there was a cracker I climbed b4 reaching Bristol.. I’ll need try find out what it was called I’ll check through my Strava. Thoroughly enjoyed the whole thing tho.
data.author: Mark Vance

data.text: Can't remember any on my route - I think between Glastonbury and Bristol it was all pretty much flat.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: its a good bike for climbing dome quite alot of big climbs on the gravel but im new to bike-packing/touring so wasnt sure what it would be like loaded up on the hills going for bar,frame,saddle bags mate
data.author: Joshua Wilson

data.text: Yes 1x drivetrain is fine, less things to break. If it is very steep and rough the chances are you are going to get off and push if the bike is heavily loaded anyway. No point killing yourself on the first hill climb of the day. Unless you are a hill climb pain addict you will do a lot of pushing :)
data.author: Jim McNeil
